cons: Work/life balance here means don't ever let your life get in the way of work from 7am to 4pm. Mana… gers there love people that will not speak up when given impossible tasks or when told blatant lies. Managers all manage up, meaning they want you to say you are on top of everything so they can go back to their meetings. When something falls through the cracks, they want to be able to say you didn't ask for help. They do not want you to actually ask for help, and if you do they will burn your time up justifying what you've been doing every minute, but they never take anything off your task list.The few Managers I saw that actually spent time trying to help their team get their jobs done were laid off or demoted. Everything new that is rolled out is presented with the punishments for not complying. I never saw a new initiative or process rolled out with rewards or positive encouragement. Every failure, even mechanical breakdowns like welds breaking, are viewed as personal discipline issues because a good engineer knows the condition of all their systems. If you asked to upgrade the system and got turned down, the failure is your fault because you didn't specify when and how it was going to fail, and you didn't re-submit your request with better justification.I had an alarm that went unattended for 2 hours and caused a problem. One root cause was that they just laid off 2 of the 3 job positions that were supposed to respond to the alarm and hadn't figured out a backfill plan yet (normally 3 job positions are all supposed to make sure the alarms are handled). Two of the three were laid off, the ops tech was busy repairing other broken equipment, and the managers at the incident review rejected those root causes. The only root cause accepted was the ops tech thought the alarm was not critical and took two hours to respond. The solution adopted was to change the alarm message to sound more critical.I've worked for many companies, and I've never seen a place where deception by omission is the only way to keep your job.

cons: I worked at Intel for 8 1/2 years. The last couple of years were my most passionate and my greatest frustration. While none of my managers were malicious, their net effect was categorically abusive. I simultaneously had a skillset that was too critical to my server project to allow me to take an offered SoC "Hot Job" (jobs identified as critical for the company's future), but not worthy enough to address the career g… rowth reasons for my dissatisfaction with the project that led me to want to leave, but they still offered me nearly half a years pay to voluntarily separate from the company to make space to hire more engineers for SoC. Let that sink in - I had been offered an SoC-related engineering job and my group blocked my transfer then offered me a large buyout to leave the company because they needed to make room to hire SoC engineers. Again, nobody was being malicious here, but I was in the middle of three different ridiculous circumstances caused by decision of three different levels of management all acting in what, at some level, was the most rational thing for them to do. At no point did anybody stand up to say "the company is paying a good engineer we could use in SoC to leave the company. That doesn't seem right."Intel will tell you largely and loudly about how much they value the people working there, but they have erected systemic barriers that allow pathological levels of cruelty towards these same people. Intel will shout until they are Intel-blue-in-the-face that they have these wonderful systems for recognizing and rewarding accomplishments, but they're very inconsistent in their use. I worked on my own time for two years creating an architectural firmware debugging GUI tool. After it was announced that I was leaving, architects and engineers from different teams and different projects popped up to make sure that the source code would be available once I was gone. Over 400 hours of my own time creating it, other engineers apparently thinking that preservation of the source for it was of paramount importance, yet it was never deemed enough of an accomplishment for either recognition or reward. I can think of few more stinging ways to wound a departing engineer. When the buyout offer was extended to everyone, 5 acceptees were asked to delay their departure because their skills were needed badly. I was one of those 5 and to this day one of my greatest regrets of my 8 years at Intel was agreeing to it.I offer this example for illustrative purposes to demonstrate the dysfunctional connection between Intel's intentions, and Intel's actions. That last tool was not the first time I had identified a need, spent my own time providing a solution, had the tool picked up by many other engineers but received no notice from management until I moved on -- it was the third. The problem is systemic with deep roots. It also isn't why I left. I left because my career growth was dependent on the cooperation of a junior engineer who was getting rewarded with annual review bullet points for non-cooperation.
advice: Think about the Intel values and think about how you are using them. They're good values, but worthless if they're little more than filler on the back of your badge calendar. My manager sat in a cube 600 miles away held 30 minute 1:1's with me on average once every 3 weeks. When I complained up the management chain, nobody thought this was something that deserved attention. My manager assured me that he understood my…  concerns and had a good sense of what was going on. When the auto-generated emails from Taleo started arriving, his first question to me was: "what can we do to keep you here?" Apparently he didn't actually know my concerns. He pleaded with me to wait just a little longer before accepting anything, which I did. When the server group GM enabled management to block transfers for 6 months, all such pleading stopped. Are you listening to your direct reports? Do you know what they're working on? Do you recognize when they go the extra mile for the project? Do you confront conflict between engineers constructively or do you ignore it and tell them to "deal with it"? Is the best tool in your belt the ability to delay dealing with a report's concerns until you can argue that addressing something that far in the past would do more harm than good? In 1:1's do any of your reports have to spend most of their time telling you what they've been working on because you can't remember?
pros: Your colleagues can easily become your best friends. Work/life balance was very good. cons: Over two years working in one of Intel's product strategy units [not engineering and I think that's important to discern], I met some awesome people but overall, I found little challenge, inspiration, or vision in the company and its culture. I often felt like the company as a whole was on auto-drive, sticking to management styles, roadmaps, lifestyles that were familiar and comfortable to them, rather than taking ri… sks and seeking true, sustainable positive changes. I witnessed an idea rejected because it wasn't on a years-old roadmap and thus deemed impossible to execute; Apple came out with devices that implemented the idea 6 months later. I sat in many meetings where the audience typed furiously on their laptops or snored loudly over the conference call during the presentation, giving 0 cares, or they pigeon-holed on a completely unrelated topic that delayed crucial decision-making. Everything at Intel felt like it moved slowly, bogged down by tradition and its resulting band-aid fixes/decisions.I also encountered serious issue with the company's management selection scheme. Managers seemed to be chosen based on how long they've been at Intel or what's on their outdated resume, rather than their demonstrated merits and character. When respected colleagues approached my manager requesting to change projects due to consistent sexist and demeaning comments made by the project manager, they were immediately told to quit whining or start looking for new jobs. When I approached my manager with concern that I felt unchallenged, was not experiencing growth, and reaching my potential, he told me that I shouldn't worry since learning the organization chart and how the different business units interacted with each other was still a major achievement.... UH, NO.... not after I've been there for about 2 years and I regularly expressed to him my goal to build my technical expertise.In summary, based on my experience, Intel has some great people but if you're looking for serious growth and inspiration as a non-engineering designer, this is not the place you will find it.
advice: Do a better job of selecting management.Target some women empowerment initiatives at educating men that compose the majority of your work force.Provide benefits oriented towards younger, single (no kids) workers.Commit and really spell out a single vision and it's practical implications on your workers.

cons: Let's start with blue badge cons: sabbaticals are great when you are on them, and extremely stressful when important co-workers are on them. More than a few people quit or transferred because of other people's poorly-planned sabbaticals. On the other hand, some people at Intel are so useless, you don't even notice that they're gone until their cube is decorated for their return. It is very much a secret society; if y… ou are liked by everyone, you will work there forever. If you are disliked, you will find yourself in redeployment regardless of how much of a rock star you are. The technology at Intel (and the IT department in general) is ironically bland, old, and limited. You will not be working with cutting edge technology at Intel unless you're directly involved with creating it. There is shockingly little innovation at the company because whenever a new problem arises or a new business idea is funded, they put the same old grey ghosts in charge of it. If your previous job was at a tech startup, Intel will feel like Soviet Russia to you -- big, cold, slow, mundane, hostile toward change, dominated by senseless rules and old traditions, secretly pleased with the failure of new initiatives, and governed by oligarchs. Most people are decent, but some people are untouchable and they know it: many 10k and 100k managers, architects, and everyone above them. They are free to do and say whatever they want, they can and will flagrantly disobey rules and disregard standards, and they can eliminate your budget, cancel your project, or even force you into redeployment or resignation if you really stand in the way. If you want to make a difference, do not go to Intel. Do not expect to be employed long-term unless you are working on a product that is actively making a ton of money for the company. Green badge contractors are often fired for no reason with no warning and no severance. If you are a green badge at Intel, expect not to have a job tomorrow, be glad if you still do, and always be looking for your next job.
advice: Stop with the re-orgs and bipolar decision-making. Eliminate the perks that attract long-term bloodsuckers and focus harder on benefits that attract risk-takers... figure out how to be competitive with startups instead of trying to be competitive with the US Postal Service. Look up Jane Elliott's "Blue Eyes Brown Eyes Exercise" so that you can learn a famous and well-documented lesson about discrimination based on co… lor (even if it's the color of the plastic around your neck, the same results apply). Maybe the Stanford Prison Experiment as well. Use more short-term contractors to fill in for sabbatical coverage so your high-achievers don't get burned out. Modernize everything in the same ways that ARM and nVidia have. The only part of Intel that isn't old and rusty is the manufacturing group.
pros: This depends on the color of your badge. Blue badge employees or ICE contractors have a lot of perks -- free tickets to major sports games and shows, on-site events, little freebies like coffee and fruit. You are entitled to a one-month sabbatical every 4 years, or a two-month sabbatical every 7 years. There aren't layoffs in the traditional sense; instead, Intel will offer voluntary separation agreements (big severa… nce check) or redeployment (you can still get paid while you desperately apply for other positions within Intel, and are given priority hiring status). Most people at the company are pleasant and professional (some are NOT; see the cons section for details). If you play your cards right, you can coast here for 30+ years and get a marvelous retirement at the end. The people who are happiest at Intel are those who don't really care about the outcome of anything. They just show up, log their time, complete their work to spec and on deadline, follow the rules, don't make waves, and go home at 5. If that sounds like you, then you will love Intel. That really isn't any different from any other huge corporation, but Intel will give you better long-term benefits. Now on to green badges: the one and only pro is that you will get paid for the time you enter into your timecard.
summary: Know exactly what you are getting into and don't dare to hope

cons: BK initiated a blacklist for 1000+ employees in June of 2015.Surprised, shocked, disheartened. For a company earning billions in Net Profits even despite the constant cry-wolf of "we need to tighten our belts, we're in trouble, we need to deliver more 'value' to 'shareholders' (who I feel are just an artificial and convenient proxy for "I want to do something tough but I don't want to accept responsibility fo… r it, so I'll blame a crowd of nameless, impossible-to-identify people who probably aren't even rattling the cage any harder than any other company").It made me sick of the corporate doublespeak and feeling of being treated like cattle who (as long as you don't speak the truth in front of them) will never actually understand what's going on around them until the bolt crosses their skull directly.Hearing all the individual stories from colleagues (of people hit by this death-by-spreadsheet action) makes me glad I'm no longer part of Intel - decided to move after years of ignoring my own gut sense that Intel has terminal cancer and will never shake off its 40 years of fossilized "culture" (which is just a polite way of saying "habit" and "bullying" in one palatable syllable) and may never turn into an organization that values risk-taking, actions-over-ass-covering and investing in the long-term of its people resources.
advice: Admit you're focusing the company on silicon to the exclusion of all else, or get out of the factory mindset and spend more time learning how to run the non-silicon parts of the business.

cons: I formed a very low opinion of higher / senior level management. Within the company, they essentially encourage what a good friend of mine called a "clan war". I happen to work in MCG (mobile communication group) that throughout my time (3.5 year) was reorganized 6 times(!). Many times the multi-month work of whole department (not only my team) was thrashed, because some new boss would come and "not favor" your team … and whatever result was done to that date.Global cross-team coordination effort was very low to non-existent. Teams would "fight" for resources, and have a quite unhealthy competition. Decision would be made with some irrelevant considerations, and forced down to my team.As result, the culture actually experienced would not be really engaging.The performance review process is essentially botched. Some much higher management essentially issues a quota on number of good performance ratings to your team. Then, you end up in a situation when no matter how much you tried, you'd be stuck at your performance grade, because no good rating can be made available to you (again despite the acknowledgement of high level of contribution and such). Example: our team received only one EE (exceeds expectations) rating, and my manager decided to use it to promote one particular employee (citing his family situation (he had a new child, etc), and his current lower grade). Others were given S (satisfactory) rating
advice: fire most of senior management as incapable
pros: Pay is generally very good, 2 extra bonus programs, especially if you're in higher grade.You may get to travel to different GEOs - our team had collaborating divisions all over the world (Finland, Israel, Netherlands, S.Korea, Taiwan). Good opportunity to see places. I traveled 2-3 times a year being in an engineering role.Some good positive aspects of the culture - Intel has a "work-week" (WW) based schedule…  (simpler to learn and more efficient), it at least declares a lot of good intentions (but in practice you may find a different picture), all kind of training is available to employees (a lot of mandatory programs).Intel has plenty of relationships in the industry. My team ended up facing customers in "deep technical dive" support programs, I got to work with all big industry names: Samsung, Asus, HP, Dell, Sharp, Sony, to name a few.
summary: Your experience will vary depending on factors you don't control

cons: Horrible management. No communication. No loyalty to long time employees. Horrible hiring practices. Care more about making money than making their employees happy, at least on the manufacturing side.
advice: Intel used to feel like a family. New management practices have killed that feeling. Now it's all clinical, which is understandable from a business standpoint, but the people are what made the company what it is. The new practices will definitely generate more dollars right now, but innovation will die out when people aren't happy to come to work anymore. I know that at least half of the manufacturing staff, that I w… as a part of, no longer wants to be a part of Intel, but only stays because of the paycheck. Five years ago, that wasn't the case. I was let go because of one bad review at the wrong time, after all these years, but I'm not bitter. I was relieved to be done with it. I was one of the people only staying for the paycheck. Part of my Intel family is still there, and I hope that things can get back to, or at least close to, the way things were, for their sake.

cons: You don't really get to decide where they put you. If you are unlucky you will get stuck with a group or project that is at a major disadvantage compared to other groups and will consequently be a major burden until the next technology node is reached. There is no work-life balance. Intel owns you 24/7. Vacations are permitted but not without a penalty before or after you leave. Management style is very archaic. Feed… back from any employee in manufacturing is disregarded because the "if it isn't broken, don't fix it" philosophy prevails among those in upper management. They pay you 20% more than average but expect 100% more of your time than other companies (80-120 hrs/week is common).
advice: Fear is only a temporary motivator. It works initially to get people to do what you want but eventually people adapt to the discomfort and will usually end up doing only the minimum of what is required to get you off their back. If you are really interested in increasing productivity you need a better strategy than just working new employees to ruin and then casting them off and/or replacing them when they can't take…  it anymore. So much time gets wasted by you constantly having to replace/train your engineers. This system results three types of engineers: those who are new and don't know anything but are willing to work hard, those who are experienced enough to know how not to work hard and get away with it, and those in the middle who are always on the verge of giving (either quitting or losing their self respect and becoming like every other senior engineer who does only a minimal job).
pros: There are great engineers to work with, the pay is above average and benefits good. There is also a certain amount of notoriety in the industry for someone working in the technology development part of Intel.

cons: Job security lacking. Taking away resources while expecting higher performance.
advice: Learn how to value your employees again.
pros: Good pay and benefits, but these have been reduced over the years

cons: If you are new you are nothing. Your previous experience does not mean anything. Huge, impersonal environment.

cons: Intel's long time CEO (Paul Otellini) "jumped ship" and the new CEO (Brian Krzanich) has not performed to expectations. Many top managers have left the company and now BK's right hand (Renee James) is also "jumping ship". One of Brian's strategy is to let go of experienced middle aged employees (35+) and replaced them with low paid interns and recent college graduates in order to cut costs (He recently fired ~4k empl… oyees who had been with the company for years and said more layoffs will continue). In one of his speeches to Intel Employees, he said that employees are disposable, all that matters is the survival of the corporation, continuity of Moore's Law and the name of the corporation. He has taken away many of employee perks: Work from home day, work life balance, team builder off-site's, etc... The moral of Intel employees is down and there is no job security - Therefore, employees are not performing at their best. Management group is very "clicky" - they hire their friends and help them get into Mgmt by giving them top job reviews - but no one dares say anything because even though the feedback says "confidential" they are not - and once you get on the bad side of one manager, you are sunk. If you do a job really well and then want to move to a different position, your direct manager has complete control of your carrier development and may keep you on one role for as long as they want. Focal (yearly job reviews) are a joke... they have to be written by the employee in third person because managers are to lazy to write them and no matter how long you spend or how good you have sold yourself, the manager will still give top reviews to their preferred employees. Standard pay raises are between 0 and 3% per year - as of recent, pay raises average about 1%, since the corporation is going through financial stress - a 1% pay raise does not even cover the increase of cost of living.Is it a good place to work? Yes it is - but do not stay on one job for more than a year and be ready to leave after 3 to 5 years. The benefit of working for Intel is mainly to get the experience on your resume - it opens bigger opportunities - better pay - elsewhere.
advice: Management does not take accountability nor responsibility - The role of a manager is also to look after the best interest of its employees: Opportunities, development, learning experience, career development, etc... - the success of an employee reflects directly on the manager - as well as the failures. Intel Management lacks all that - so do not expect much from your manager, unless you got the job using them and y… ou are in their group of personal friends.
pros: Large corporation where experience and skills may be attained. Some co-workers are very smart and some of them willing to mentor less skilled co-workers. Access to work across multiple divisions and gain a world of knowledge and experience. If working is your passion - this is the place for you.
